Are you sure, you want to continue - interview
"Both Month and Year don't be zero!!"
The name of head of the household corresponds to the line listing data.
Name of new head of the household
Any sign suggestive of bone or joint infection
Did the signs appear within first 24 hours of birth?
Was child admitted in any hospital within last 2 weeks?
Has child taken any injectable antibiotic in last 48 hours?
Is child currently enrolled in any other research study?
Does the child have moderate CSI?
Does the child have critical illness signs?
Can the child be included in PSBI trial?
Does the already included child have any exclusion criteria?
Baby advised admission but family refused
Baby advised referral but family refused
MODULE H: HOUSEHOLD AND MEMBERS INFORMATION
The enumerator will read out the consent for understanding of respondent and will mention the purpose of the study and time required to complete the interview.
If written consent is not given STOP interview and move to Question H113 of this section to REFUSED on the outcome of the interview
No household member at home or no competent respondent at home at time of visit
Entire household absent for extended period
Dwelling vacant or address not a dwelling
Note: This Section will only be filled once for the Head of Household
Self-employed in agriculture and non-agriculture sector
NOTE: Instructions: This section will be filled by the Head of the household (HH) or knowledgeable member at-least 18 years old
How many members are living in this household?
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED AS PER THE RESPONSES IN BELOW QUESTIONS
Does this HH have children 0-59 months of age?
If Yes, Numbers of children 0-59 months
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED
Does this HH have children 05-09 years of age?
If Yes, Numbers of children 05-09 years
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED
Does this HH have Adolescent 10-19 years of age?
If Yes, Numbers of children 10-19 years
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED
Does this HH have members 20-49 years of age?
If Yes, Numbers of members 20-49 years
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED
Does this HH have members greater than the age of 49 years of age?
If Yes, Numbers of members greater than 49 years
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED
Total Number of Members older than 49 years
Number of Women of Reproductive Age (WRA) living in the household who are aged between 15 to 49 years?
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED
SECTION H2: Married Women of Reproductive Age (MWRA) Information
THIS SECTION WILL BE REPEATED AS PER THE TOTAL NUMBER OF MWRA ENTERED IN H220
Note: This Section will be filled only for Married Women of Reproductive Age (MWRA) have child under 06-59 months of age
Please implement the age calculation w.r.t DOB, if incase if DOB is not known user must enter 98 for Date, 98 for Month, 9998 for Year. Than user can manually enter age.
Self-employed in agriculture and non-agriculture sector
Number of Children between 6-59 months of age
TOTAL NUMBERS WILL BE AUTO CALCULATED
Total Number of children cannot be equal to Zero
SECTION H2: Children information 06-59 months of age
Note: This section will be filled for the children of selected MWRA
Please implement the age calculation w.r.t DOB, if incase if DOB is not known user must enter 98 for Date, 98 for Month, 9998 for Year. Than user can manually enter age
Instructions: This section will be filled by the Head of the household (HH) or knowledgeable member at-least 18 years old
What is the mother tongue of the head of the household?
What is ownership status of household?
What is the main source of drinking water in your household?
Tube well or borehole or suction pump
How long does it usually take you to go to your main water source, get water, and come back? This Relates to Drinking Water
Record the number of minutes if known (record 000 if on premises or delivered to home and 998 if unknown)
Do you take any step to make the water safer to drink?
What do you usually do to make the water safe to drink?
What type of toilet facilities do you usually use in your household?
Do you share this toilet facility with other households?
If yes, how many other households use this toilet facility?
What is done to dispose the stools of the youngest child?
Put/rinsed on into toilet or latrine
Does any member of this household own:
Observe what appliances are being used for source of light in the household.
What type of fuel do you usually use for cooking in your household?
Is the cooking usually done in the house, in a separate room/space, or outdoors?
Do you have a separate room which is used as a kitchen?
Main material of the dwelling floor
Main material of the exterior walls
How many rooms in your household are used for sleeping?
Does any member of this household own any agricultural land?
If yes, how many hectares or “hissa” of agricultural land do members of this household own?
IF H322 IS 98 H322A AND H322B SHOULD BE DISABLED
Do you have your own livestock, animals, or poultry?
If yes, how many livestock, animals or poultry does your household own?
Ask for each listed animals, one by one and observation by enumerator Insert 000 if none OR Record 999 for >999
Please show us where you and members of your household most often wash their hands.
Observe presence of water at the specific place for hand washing.
Record if soap or detergent is present at the specific place for hand washing
IF USER SELECTS H403E ABOVE OPTIONS SHOULD BE DISABLED
Do you have any soap or detergent in your household for hand washing?
If yes, can you please show it to me?
IF USER SELECTS H405E ABOVE OPTIONS SHOULD BE DISABLED
In what situations do you wash your hands with soap?
[This is an open-ended question. Do not read the answer choices Probe]
After defecating or using the latrine
We would like to check whether the salt used in your household is iodised. May I have a sample of the salt used to cook meals in your household?
Apply 2 drops of test solution, observe the darkest reaction within 30 seconds, compare to the colour chart and then record the response (1, 2 or 3) that corresponds to test outcome in H501
Observe the texture of the salt being used
Observe “Salt Iodization” Logo printed or not?
SECTION H6: Household Food Insecurity Access Scale (HFIAS) Measurement Tool
In the past four weeks, did you worry that your household would not have enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, were you or any household member not able to eat the kinds of foods you preferred because of a lack of resources?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member have to eat a limited variety of foods due to a lack of resources?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member have to eat some foods that you really did not want to eat because of a lack of resources to obtain other types of food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member have to eat a smaller meal than you felt you needed because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any other household member have to eat fewer meals in a day because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, was there ever no food to eat of any kind in your household because of lack of resources to get food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member go to sleep at night hungry because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member go a whole day and night without eating anything because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (three to ten times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
SECTION H7. ASSISTANCE & EXPOSURE TO INTERVENTIONS
Note: Interviewer will show the Food Products during the interview
In past 30 days, did anyone in your household receive the following assistance?
In past 30 days, did anyone in your household receive any other assistance?
In past 30 days, did anyone in your household receive any other assistance?
MODULE W: WOMEN OF REPRODUCTIVE AGE
THIS MODULE IS TO BE ADMINISTERED TO WOMEN IDENTIFIED IN THE HOUSEHOLD TO BE BETWEEN 15 AND 49 YEARS OF AGE.
What is your date of birth?
If day is not known, enter ‘98’ If year is not known, enter’9998’ If month is not known, enter ‘98’
Please tell me how old you are. What was your age at your last birthday? Record age in completed years
Check W101 and W102: is the respondent between the ages of 15 and 49 years? If the information in W101 and W102 conflicts, determine which is most accurate.
What was your age, at the time of your marriage?
How many times you have been pregnant in your life? (Including current Pregnancy)
How many times have you delivered in your life?
W108 CANNOT BE GREATER THAN W107
What was age at the time of first birth?
How many times you have been Pregnant during last five years? (Including current Pregnancy)
W110 CANNOT BE GREATER THAN W107
How many times have you delivered during last five years?
W111 CANNOT BE GREATER THAN W108 AND W110
Was there a live birth in last five years?
W109 cannot be less than W105
W108 cannot be greater than W107
W110 cannot be greater than W107
W111 cannot be greater than W110
DETAILS OF ALL PREGNANCIES IN LAST FIVE YEARS
THIS TABLE IS FOR SELECTED MWRA AGED BETWEEN 15-49 YEARS. IT WILL BE REAPEATED DEPENDING ON THE NUMBER OFPREGNANCY ENTERED IN W107 YEAR OF OUTCOME IS MANDATORY TO RECORD
Was the baby born alive, born dead or lost before birth?
How old was the child when he/she died?
To be filled for Selected WRAs 15 to 49 years of age having child 6-59 months
Did you see anyone for antenatal care during your last pregnancy with (name)?
Probe: Anyone else? Probe for the type of person seen and record all answers given.
Where did you seek antenatal care
How many weeks or months pregnant were you when you first received antenatal care during last pregnancy?
Record the answer as stated by respondent. If “9 months” or later, record 9.
How many times did you receive antenatal care during last pregnancy?
Probe to identify the number of times antenatal care was received. If a range is given, record the minimum number of times antenatal care received.
As part of your antenatal care during your pregnancy, were any of the following done at least once:
W20697 AND W20696 WILL APPEAR AFTER W20808, IF USER SELECTS W20697 ALL OTHER OPTIONS WILL BE DISABLED, AND THE RESPONSES IN THOSE OPTION WILL ALSO BE DISABLED
Have you ever taken any iron folic acid (IFA) while you were pregnant?
At what time of pregnancy did you start taking IFA?
Who advised to take any iron folic acid (IFA) while you were pregnant?
From Where did you get iron folic acid (IFA) while you were pregnant?
How often did you take IFA during pregnancy?
How many months or days did you take IFA?
Have you ever taken calcium tablets while you were pregnant?
Who advised to take calcium tables while you were pregnant?
From Where did you get calcium tables while you were pregnant?
How often did you take calcium tablets during pregnancy?
How many months or days did you take calcium tablets?
Was deworming tablet were given to you during pregnancy?
Did you use the deworming tablets?
Did you feel you had night blindness (difficulty in seeing clearly in dusk) during your last pregnancy?
How long ago did PHC OR CHP’S health professional last visited your household?
How often does your PHC staff or CHP’s health professional visit your household?
What was the purpose of PHC staff or CHP’s health professional’s last visit?
When did PHC staff or CHP’s health professional last conduct a health and nutrition session?
Have you ever attended one of her health and nutrition sessions?
How often do you attend these sessions?
(To be filed for Selected WRA aged 15 to 49 having under 5 child)
Who assisted with the delivery of (name)?
Probe: Anyone else? Probe for the type of person assisting and record all answers given.
Where did you give birth to (name)?
What was the type of delivery
When (name) was born, was s/he very large, larger than average, average, smaller than average or very small?
If a card is available, record weight from card.
Within one hour after birth, was (name) put directly on the bare skin of your chest?
Was (name) dried or wiped soon after birth?
Before being placed on the bare skin of your chest, was the baby wrapped up?
How long after the birth was (name) bathed for the first time?

If “immediately” or less than 1 hour, record ‘00’. \r\n If less than 24 hours, record hours. If “1 day” or “next day”, probe: About how many hours after the delivery? If “24 hours”, probe to ensure best estimate of less than 24 hours or 1 day. If 24 hours or more, record days.
After the cord was cut and until it fell off, was anything applied to the cord?
IF W312 IS 1 THAN OPTIONS IN W313 WILL APPEAR FROM 2 TO 98 AND IF W312 IS 2 THAN ONLY FIRST OPTION IS W313 WILL APPEAR
What was applied to the cord?
If Chlorhexidine was used ask the respondent about the source of provision?
Did anyone check on your health after delivery? (During the postnatal period 42 days)
Who checked your health after delivery?
How long after delivery did the first of these checks happen?
If less than one day, record hours. If less than one week, record days. Otherwise, record weeks.
How many times such check happen?
Did anyone check on (name of child) health?
Who checked the child’s health after delivery?
How long after delivery did the first of these checks happen?
If less than one day, record hours. If less than one week, record days. Otherwise, record weeks.
How many times such check happen?
Have you ever used contraception methods to avoid pregnancy
Are you currently using any contraception method to avoid pregnancy
If Yes What contraception methods, you are using
SECTION: W4 MINIMUM DIETARY DIVERSITY FOR WOMEN (15-49 YEARS)
Instructions: Only one WRA will be selected for this section

Ask the women about her diet which she has taken yesterday after she wake up till, she went to bed for sleep. Refer to the Food Group Booklet to identify and elaborate the food item and record its utilization in the table below
Grains, White Roots and Tubers, and Plantains
Barley, Millet, Oats, Rice, Sorghum, Wheat, Arracacha, Bananas, Cassava, Lotus Root, Potatoes (all skin colors), Rutabaga, Sweet Potato (White, pale yellow fleshed), arbi/arvi
Adzuki Bean, Broad Bean, Chickpeas, Cluster Bean, Common Bean, Lentil, Mung Bean, Pea, Pigeon Pea, Rice bean, Soybean (Soya Bean), Urad Bean
Peanut/Groundnut, Almond, Cashew, Pistachio, Walnut, Wild Mango (Bush Mango), Locust Bean Seeds, Melon Seeds, Pine Nuts, Pumpkin Seeds, Sesame Seeds, Sunflower Seeds
Fresh Whole, Low Fat, Skim milk, reconstituted powdered or evaporated or ultra-high temperature (UHT) boxed milk, Hard cheese, Soft cheese, Kefir, Yoghurt/Curd

Beef, Goat, Mutton, Lamb, Rabbit, Yak, Deer, Antelope, Buffalo or other large wild or domesticated mammals, Tripe or other pale organ meats, Chicken, Duck, Goose, Guinea Fowl, Pigeon, Turkey, Other wild or domesticated birds, Gizzard, Heart, Kidney, Liver, Fresh/Frozen/Dried Fish (all species), Canned Fish (Tuna and Sardines), Shrimp, Lobster, Carbs
Chicken Eggs and Duck Eggs, Egg powder

Bean Greens, Beet Greens, Bitter Melon Greens, Broccoli, Carrots Green, Chicory Greens, Chilli Greens, Chinese cabbage, Fenugreek Greens (Methi), Lettuce, Mustard Green, Okra Greens (Lady Fingers), Pumpkin Green, Spinach, Turnip Greens
Other Vitamin A-rich Fruits and Vegetables

Apricot (Fresh or Dried), Cantaloupe Melon (Ripe), Locust Bean Fruit/Pulp, Mango (Ripe, Fresh and Dried), Musk Melon, Papaya (Ripe, fresh and dried), Peaches (dried or raw), Persimmon (ripe), Carrot, Pumpkin, Red Pepper (sweet), Squash (Orange or dark yellow fleshed only), Sweet Potato (Orange or Dark yellow fleshed only)

Asparagus, Beans (various) when eaten as fresh pod, Beets, Bitter melon, Cabbage (Common and Red varieties), Cauliflower, Celery, Corn (fresh, not dried /flour/meal - Green Maize), Cucumbers, Eggplant (Brinjal), Green Pepper, Leek, Lettuce (Light Green), Mushroom, Okra, Onion, Pea’s green, Radish, Tomato, Zucchini

Apple, Avocado, Banana, Blackberry, Blueberry, Cherries, Coconut Flesh, Dates (Fresh and dried), Grapefruit, Grapes, Guava, Honeydew Melon, Indian Gooseberry (Amla), Jujube, Kiwi, Lemon, Lime, Litchi, Mandarin Orange, Mulberry, Orange, Peach, Pear, Pineapple, Plum, Pomegranate, Pomelo, Rambutan, Raspberry, Sapodella (naseberry), Star Fruit, Strawberry, Sweetsop, Tamarind, Tangerine, Watermelon
MODULE C: CHILD NUTRITION UNDER 5 YEARS
Module C is for children under five years of age, specific sections will be filled as per the age of the Selected children in the household.
SECTION C1: IYCF AND FOOD DIVERSITY (FD)
For child between age -6-59 months of age
QUESTIONS ABOUT FEEDING IMMEDIATELY AFTER BIRTH
How long after birth was [NAME] first put to the breast?
If immediately, ENTER “000” If less than one hour, record “00” hours If less than 24 hours, record hours Otherwise, record days
In the first two days after delivery, was [NAME] given anything other than breast milk to eat or drink – anything at all like water, infant formula,
or [ MASKA/BUTTER IS TRADITIONAL insert common drinks and foods, including ritual feeds, that may be given to newborn infants]?
QUESTIONS ABOUT CURRENT BREAST- AND BOTTLE FEEDING
Was [NAME] breastfed yesterday during the day or at night?
Did [NAME] drink anything from a bottle with a nipple yesterday during the day or at night?
Now I would like to ask you about liquids that [NAME] had yesterday during the day or at night.
Please tell me about all drinks, whether [NAME] had them at home, or somewhere else. Yesterday during the day or at night, did [NAME] have?
Infant formula, such as [insert local names of common formula] NAN, NUTRILAK, NESTLE, NESTOGEN, SIMILAK
If “yes”: How many times did [NAME] drink formula? If 7 or more, record “7” If number of times not known, record “99”
Milk from animals, such as fresh, tinned, or powdered milk?
If “yes”: How many times did [NAME] drink milk? If 7 or more, record “7” If number of times not known, record “99”
If “yes”: Was the milk or were any of the milk drinks a sweet or flavored type of milk?
Yogurt drinks such as [insert local names of common types of yogurt drinks
If “yes”: How many times did [NAME] drink yogurt? If 7 or more, record “7” If number of times not known, record “99”
If “yes”: Was the yogurt or were any of the yogurt drinks a sweet or flavored type of yogurt drink?
Chocolate-flavored drinks including those made from syrups or powders?
Fruit juice or fruit-flavored drinks including those made from syrups or powders?
Sodas, malt drinks, sports drinks, or energy drinks?
If “yes”: Was the drink/ Were any of these drinks sweetened?
If “yes”: Was the drink or were any of these drinks sweetened?

Now I would like to ask you about foods that [NAME] had yesterday during the day or at night. I am interested in foods your child ate whether at home or somewhere else. Please think about snacks and small meals as well as main meals.

I will ask you about different types of foods, and I would like to know whether your child ate the food even if it was combined with other foods in a mixed dish like [list common local examples of mixed dishes]
Please do not answer “yes” for any food or ingredient used in a small amount to add flavor to a dish.
Yesterday during the day or at night, did [NAME] eat
If “yes”: How many times did [NAME] eat yogurt?
Plantains, white potatoes, white yams, manioc, cassava
Sausages, hot dogs/frankfurters, ham, bacon, salami, canned meat
Any other meat, such as beef, pork, lamb, goat, chicken, duck
Fresh or dried fish or shellfish?
Beans, peas, lentils, nuts, seeds or [insert commonly consumed foods made from beans, peas, lentils, nuts, or seeds]?
Sweet foods such as chocolates, candies, pastries, cakes, biscuits, or frozen treats like ice cream and popsicles
Chips, crisps, puffs, French fries, fried dough, instant noodles
Any other solid, semi-solid or soft food? If “yes”: What was the food ?
CHECK C107A through C107R. If not a single “yes” is recorded, ask 7S. If at least one “yes” for C107A–C107R, skip to C108
Did [NAME] eat any solid, semi-solid or soft food yesterday during the day or at night ?
If “yes” probe: What kind of solid, semi-solid or soft foods did [NAME] eat ?
How many times did [NAME] eat any solid, semi-solid or soft foods yesterday during the day or night?
If 7 or more times, record “7” If number of times not known, record “99”
SECTION C2: FOOD CONSUMPTION AND DIET DIVERSITY FOR Children 2-5 years
Only for selected child of 2-5 years
Yesterday, how many meals did your child eat:
How does this compare to usual?

Please describe the foods (meals and snacks) that your child 2-5 years of age, ate yesterday during the day and night, whether at home or outside the home. Start with the first food eaten in the morning.

Note: Write down all food and drinks mentioned by the respondent. When the respondent has finished, probe for meals and snacks not mentioned. consider foods eaten by your child 2-5 years of age, and exclude foods purchased and eaten outside of the home]

corn/maize, rice, wheat, sorghum, millet or any other grains or foods made from these (e.g., bread, noodles, porridge, or other grain products) + insert local foods e.g., ugali, nshima, porridge or pastes or other locally available grains

VITAMIN A RICH VEGETABLES AND TUBERS
